Posted: May 3, 2014
												I love retro-style horror games. Games like Silent Hill and Resident Evil and of course the beautiful scarefest that is Amnesia depend on extraordinary graphics in order to get the scares across. In Lone Survivor the creators relied on classic pixelization, and it somehow works. The music is paranoia-inducing and the alarming change in environment when a monster sees you is reminiscent of the Silent Hill 'monster warning system" of radio static, and of Amnesia's blaring horn/string frenzy of "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ They see me!!". And much like Silent Hill there are quite a few monsters to navigate around and it is not expected that you outright battle them head-on, as well as many doors and openings that are not always open and, as far as you know, may never be. Your character claims to be the only survivor in the apartment complex that he is currently a tenant of, residing in his own cozy little room of 206. Of course, you need to go out and fetch supplies and try to find survivors. Along the way you are shaken up by bizarre visions that may be a result of something alien and supernatural--I mean seriously, that's all that could explain the existence of those THINGS--or possibly your character's insanity slowly grabbing at his mind. Despite being dumb as a rock when it comes to logical "one thing leads to another" set ups that this game surely is, I managed to find my way around the place and just as I was thinking "Okay it's time to stop for today" I found something else to explore and just kept going. This is a great mashup of pixel, adventure, psychological, thriller, and horror.

												A chilling, sometimes funny, always uncanny, thought provoking survival adventure. Not just another zombie game! It's a rich experience filled with meaning - one of those interactive pieces of fiction which is more than simply sum of its parts. Scarce yet captivating music + simplistic yet powerful visuals + disjointed yet coherent plot + surreal yet unforgettable characters = Lone Survivor. Or is he?V e r d i c t : AWESOMESAUCE, which means nearly perfect

Posted: April 25, 2014
												This game can be summed up pretty quickly: 2D Silent Hill. Lone Survivor is an indie survival horror game and if you've ever played a Silent Hill game before, this game will feel very familiar. The developer, Jasper Byrne, is a self-proclaimed Silent Hill fan and the influences are very apparent throughout the game. Everything including the gameplay, the narrative themes, and even the audio cues are very Silent Hill-esque. And Byrne, who also composed the game's soundtrack, does a great job channeling Silent Hill's Akira Yamaoka with his musical style. But even if you've never played a Silent Hill game, you may still want to give Lone Survivor a look.Lone Survivor is short, and I think that's to its credit. It's about 5 hours long, and I think that's a perfect length for a game like this. Turning off all of the lights in your house and subjecting yourself to the twisted imagery and pulse pounding terrors of a good horror game now and again is fun, but it's also kind of nerve wracking and draining. Not something to do every single night. I've played a lot of games that do a good thing effectively, but wear out their welcome by doing it over and over again for too long. I felt Lone Survivor had a very appropriate length, and I'd like to see more shorter experience games like this. I think it can work if the games are appropriately priced, but that's a whole different discussion. You play as a nameless survivor of some disease outbreak that has seemingly turned all of the world's population into mindless zombie-like monsters. The main character has holed up in his apartment to survive the disease outbreak, but is now running out of food and is curious if there are any other survivors other than himself. So you'll start to venture outside your apartment and see the horrors of the monster infested world, but you'll still return to the apartment often to rest and save. You can combat the monsters with your handgun if you have enough ammo, or you can lay piles of meat around to attract the monsters to a certain location to try and sneak past. Like any good horror game, ammo management is key. You'll want to sneak past enemies when possible rather than shooting them to conserve your ammo. You'll also want to keep an eye on how many batteries you have left. Without batteries, your flashlight won't operate and you won't be able to see many important clues and objects in your environment.While Lone Survivor probably isn't quite as complete of a game as some of the games it's influenced by, this game is still my favorite type of horror game. There are very few, if any, jump scares. Less means that the few jump scares that are in the game are more powerful and memorable. Rather than relying on jump scares, games like Silent Hill and Lone Survivor create the feeling of horror by constructing a creepy atmosphere through good music, sound and art design. Games like these understand that the most horrific things your imagination can cook up are more intense than anything the game can actually show you. So they simply focus on creating good atmosphere and let your imagination do the rest. I especially love the strange hallucinations and bizarre scenery present in Lone Survivor. Good stuff. I think the minimalist pixelated art style works to the game's favor here too. When you see a monster, you just kind of get a general impression of what it looks like, and again, your imagination fills in the details. Lone Survivor perfectly follows the prototype for my favorite kind of horror game.I didn't find the story quite as satisfying or the game design as nuanced as Silent Hill 2, but Lone Survivor is still worth a look if you like these kinds of games. Its length is appropriate, and it does a great job creating a dark and creepy atmosphere. I wish it had the narrative depth of SH2, but does do a great job replicating nearly everything else from that game.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

Posted: April 26, 2012
												A truly amazing game. It's very low-priced, so go on, buy it. You'll be glad you did. :)Still here? Cool! Wanna hear an awesome backstory? Okay... I originally bought the game direct from Jasper Byrne's superflatgames -- and little did I know I was doing so a mere day before it came out on Steam! ARGH! But since it is such a good game, I went ahead and bought it again here on Steam. Why? Well, I emailed Jasper to let him know that among all the hate mail from people feeling cheated by this move, I wanted to send him an email letting him know that I took the situation as an advantage to help out a TRUE auteur of games, by purchasing it again via Steam. He actually responded, thanking me and saying that he was going to send out Steam codes for everyone who bought the game direct from him. The guy continually out-does himself, creating every aspect of his games, from the music to the programming to the art, etc. So help this guy out, and buy this awesome game.

Posted: June 6, 2012
												A fantastic survival horror game with a distinct emphasis on survival.  Draws strong influence from Silent Hill series (no secret that the game's creator, Jasper Byrne, is a fan).  It feels like a 16-bit version of Silent Hill with a dash of Eternal Darkness thrown in.  You are a survivor of an outbreak that has devastated your city.  You awake in your apartment alone, supplies nearly exhausted and find yourself forced to confront the horrors outside to both gather life-sustaining supplies and perhaps find a way to escape the decaying city.  Along the way you will encounter mysterious figures and come to question which, if any, of these encounters even happened.  Unlike many run n' gun action survival horror games. Combat is not something encouraged and you must also take care of your basic biological needs such as eating and sleeping lest your mental health deteriorate and cause you to descend into madness.  It's a bit short but it's execution and artistic style are superb.

Posted: June 1, 2013
												Having never played through Silent Hill 2 (It never sucked me in, sorry), I played Lone Survivor and enjoyed my time with it. The atmosphere was dark and foreboding, pretty much making me summon courage every time I had to take a step foward. The monsters, while nothing to look at, did creep me out and want to stay away, but they got kind of boring after a while. Things did eventually get repetitious, but what kept me going was the music, the atmosphere and helping the main character survive. It is short, however, and I wished it could have gone on just a bit longer, but I enjoyed my playthrough. The ending I got kind of sucked, but that's what I get for killing everything. I heard the Red ending sucked more, so I think it's at least worth looking at if you like a creepy atmosphere and excellent music.

Posted: January 17, 2014
												This short but oh so sweet game is a great little survivor horror adventure game. Although it might not seem that way, the pixel art is actually really effective, together with the awesome soundtrack, in creating a perfect atmosphere. I know I'm a total wuss, but still, I was really scared and on edge the entire time.Any negative points to mention? Not really. The game isn't very hard, it's more 'adventure game light', but there is a difficulty spike somewhere in the middle that was a bit annoying, but that might've been because it was during the scariest part (that ♥♥♥♥ing basement, man!).The story is great, never really truly giving away too much, always intriguing. I really recommend this one!!![SPOILERS! WELL, NOT REALLY SPOILERS, BUT YOU MIGHT NOT WANT TO READ THIS IS YOU'RE SENSITIVE TO THAT SORT OF THING!!!]I really liked the twist, but what I liked even more is the way they chose to gradually let you have doubts on your own, and then finally find out, but without a PLOT TWIST!!! moment. Your doubts are also never really confirmed, so it keeps you guessing. Really cool way for the story to unfold, but also a really cool way to have a plot twist in a game without getting all 'JJ Abrams' about it, :-)

												If you like the Silent Hill series, you will like Lone Survivor. It's a creepy, atmospheric survival horror game with an emphasis on keeping your character fed and well rested while exploring the dark world. The throwback SNES-style graphics work very well, and are obviously inspired by SNES classics like Splatterhouse and Clock Tower. The game does a good job of creating a constant sense of dread and unease, using music and screen effects, even breaking the fourth wall occasionally. If you've got $10 available, don't buy coffee and a vegemite scroll, buy this game instead because it's worth playing.

Posted: April 29, 2012
												Whoa.  For a very old-school, 2-D side-scroller, this game is horror done right.  Granted, my nerves are pretty frayed already, but within 15 minutes I knew this was going to be a game I won't be able to play by myself (yeah, I'm a wimp; I blame stress).  The music, sound effects, and atmosphere seem very much to be a love letter to the first Silent Hill.You explore; examine; collect items; and avoid, lure, and kill enemies, all the while trying to decide what is really happening and what's just a dream or hallucination.  I've only played a little, but it seems that many things determine which direction the game takes, and the attention to detail is amazing.  If you like this sort of thing, I can already recommend it!

Posted: June 13, 2012
												This game is pretty good... but it could have been better, and because of that its actually more of a disappointment in a way.Goal is to explore the apartment complex you are in and progress towards an ending.  Horror setting is heavily inspired by Silent Hill, but honestly it went too far.   The item use / find sound being basically the same as those in the SH series is a reference.  Monsters making static distorion when they get near you is borrowing / inspiration.  Directly ripping sections from those games and using them both without storyline purpose and without original spin (locking room, object in mouth-like hole, etc) is just too blatant.On top of that, every character you meed is of the 'mysterious' archetype, save one.  When everyone has confusing dialogue, nothing makes sense.  A lot of the dialogue for the main character is definately breaking believability too.  More on that below.Also, enemies should not become invulnerable when stunned by a flare.  That is just dumb as bricks game design.Because of the nonsensical dialogue, it made me feel like my player-driven actions that I took in the game meant nothing. I shot monsters that tried to kill me, ate when complaining of hunger, slept when tired, and acted like the survivalist the game portrayed my setting as necessitating. So then why does my ending involve my character exploring a mental ward, finding a clipboard with his and room number, then entering his room, suddenly deciding he's nihilistic (after 4 game hours of survivalist behavior), taking a pill he finds there, and then lying down on the bed and having a dream of his girlfriend saying 'Hey, you found me even though you're mental and everything's ♥♥♥♥ed up. That's cool right?' The character agrees, then the credits roll. Excuse me what? Where was the survivalist drive? He even just swore revenge for a buddy he made being killed a second ago. If anything he'd react to this exactly like he did to being locked in a random room before (aforementioned direct ripoff) and exactly like a survivalist would -- "Crap I got locked in! I gotta find a way out!" There's a theory the character is insane... but then that arbitrarily obsoletes the whole story I just played through. He gave up? Not believable. Was there something I missed in the bunch of mysterious dialogue from every character I meet? Yeah, probably. Games with open storylines are best when they're actually well crafted -- A mailbox with a slot that you decide what letter to put in, not a jumped arrangement of nailed boards that you could... yeah I could jam the letter in that crooked triangle space at the top but it might fall out of all the holes in the sides and bottom.There are two other endings, but given that the one I got is likely to be the default most-common one. The others are obtained for more pacifist behaviors and another for self-destructive ones (not eating, sleeping, killing everything etc). Thus if anything, this 'default' ending shouldn't be so nonsensical and break from the theme the game has presenting the whole time.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												Lone Survivor: The Directors cut is based off of the stunning true story of a failed mission involving Navy SEALs during Operation Red Wings. For a game based off of a movie though, it kinda branches off from the story of the film. And by kinda, I mean a lot. Instead of Taliban and Al-Qaeda combatants, the developers made the decision to change them into zombies and other 'horrory' stuff. Instead of Afghanistan, it takes place in an American apartment building and city. Creative changes sure, but at least they laft the main character as kinda 'Mark Wahlburgish' and its kinda good in its own right. 9/10, wouldve preferred they stayed truer to the story but good none the less.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Jasper Byrne has created a pixellated game so immersive that 8-bit monsters become absolutely terrifying. The several mysterious personalities of Lone Survivor represent the different pieces of your character's psyche, and as the journey goes on you begin to make decisions with a certain sense of mortal and personal albatross. At no point does the game feel like a toy to be played with or a skill to be mastered. There is only survival by any means, and as a player you feel every hit taken, every shot fired, every gruesome corpse as a grave reminder of your own mortality.This is a truly rare game. It has chilling aesthetics, tense gameplay, and an immersive plot with several endings. Lone Survivor is not a scary game with cheesy jump-scares. It's a true horror survival game with an immersive environment. You won't be able to play this game in one sitting or even a couple days; the human body isn't meant to handle the stress this game imparts for more than a few hours at a time.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												Beautifully presented, but short in length, Lone Survivor is the cross-stitched Pixel-graphic grandchild of Silent Hill 2. It's somber environment increased by the soundtrack and the gutteral sounds of fleshy monsters brings everything together - from the dark apartment hallways to the dusty streets. Weapons are scarce, food and water must be gathered often and carefully, and the enemies can be avoided through discarding rotten meat or sneaking by.It's one of the best survival horror games I've played, but it's a shame that it's a tad short compared to the length of other horror games. But! It has multiple endings, each brought on by how the player done, either dying a lot, going hungry often, or shooting everything in their path.Highly recommend.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Despite being fairly short, this is one game that horror fans shouldn't miss.  As the lone survivor (teehee) of some unknown apocalyptic disaster or outbreak, you must struggle to survive on your own with your life and sanity intact.  The game focuses very much on psychological horror.  It opts for a very tense and oppressive atmosphere rather than jump scares and over the top horror cliches.  It can be argued that horror is one of the most difficult genres to break into.  Fear is a subjective response and what frightens one person may not frighten another.  While there wasn't anything that made me reach for a new pair of pants, I was certainly on the edge of my seat the entire time.  In my opinion, the best horror games are those that make you incredibly tense and afraid of the unkown.  They make your body cry out for you to quit, they make you hesitant to press on, while at the same time making you crave more.  This game did it for me, and I hope it will for you as well.In conclusion, Lone Survivor is a great horror game.  It's certainly not without it's flaws (which I haven't covered here, because they truly are minor), but will certainly not disappoint.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Today at Great Games with Wolf (Issue #1) : Lone Survivor."My name is....Doesn't really matter, I suppose.Used to know how long I've been hereNow I've got no idea."great psicological adventure that dares the player to fight their most intricate fears and question its reality, As you embody the nameless survivor you must face the harsh world that's left behind after a catastrophic-Apocaliptic-esque infection.While this game uses very common horror concepts like a dystopic world ravaged by an unknown infection and zombie-like enemies it still manages to avoid the "More of the same media" Gap by throwing a really fragile (Both Physically and Psicologically) protagonist to the mix, the same character clearly suffers from a severe case of depression (given all the horrors he has faced alone) and manages to transmit that feeling to the player, The post-apocalyptic world is indeed a nightmare, Not a bullet-frenzy zombie killing spree that some other media has led us to believe so many times before.With intricate dialogue that usually includes personification of inanimate objects and self-loathing and some hallucinations the player gets to know the background story, It would seem unexistan given that it's not directly narrated but on the contrary, it's there, waiting for you to figure it out by yourself.As you progress through the story you will notice that the survivor will often hallucinate talking with a variety of characters, often passes-out and even finds himself unable to remember doing some things (like writing on his diary). as you struggle to find food, water and enough sleep while you evade the nightmarish creatures the horrors take it's toll on the survivor's mind making the setting all the more depresing.speaking about combat and scavenging, both dynamics are present and are a core feature of the game, you have to eat to stay alive, and not just "Eat anything". Eating rotten meat and rats will allow you to stay alive, but also have a higher negative impact on the character's sanity than taking the time to find and cook the ingredients for a propper meal (even when that meal canned beans). sleep is also necesary to keep you sane, and getting too much or not enough will affect your final sanity. The combat is Reminiscent of the golden days of resident evil, only in 2D. and while it lacks the weapon variety of the former it compensates by giving you the chance to clear the whole game without firing a single bullet, Using your wits and stealth to traverse the infected-filled streets.While the creatures in the world are few in variation the character stays human and vulnerable the whole game, Making the first enemy as deadly as the last one. nonetheless the game also pushes some interesting variations to keep your♥♥♥♥♥♥scared and some giant scary monsters to keep things interesting.My final rating: 9/10Brilliantly executed.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												I'll admit, this flew under my radar. It got added on to the Humble Bundle V shortly before it ended, and I never really though much about it till I scrolled through my library and saw it, and realized I didn't even know what it was about. Well, it ends up being a delicious indie combination of Amnesia and Silent Hill all wrapped up in a nice 16bit 2-D experience. The gameplay can become slightly tedious at times when you sneak past the same monster for the 20th time or so, but it makes up for this in being a relatively short game. Essentially, it's paced very well. It's not a very difficult game, either, as you always have ways to get ammo or food or such as per pills that are always available (they get restocked everyday) yet come at the price of lowering your 'mental health' and giving you a worse ending. Which brings me to my next point: the plot. It's your typical indie horror plot, there are monsters, and they want to kill you, and there's all kinds of unexplainable things that happen that don't make sense until the very end where suddenly they make slightly more sense than they did before. It's a nice play through, really. Whether you're getting your bang for your buck is debatable.

Posted: September 12, 2012
												Lone Survivor is a brave experiment: attempting to bring a visceral horror experience with a distinctive 2D pixelated graphic is not a common thing, especially because the game must provide the player with a lot of atmosphere to make the imagination replacing what such simple graphic cannot show. To achieve this goal, J. Byrne decided to add some rpg elements to a classic side scrolling adventure game, like the necessity to properly rest and eat/drink while exploring the spectral and dangerous city. Ammunitions and supplies are scarse, enemies are tough and numerous, but exploring rewards the player with useful items. Several characters can be met during the travel, they have sidequests for the player and they also help to put together the pieces of the puzzle of a very interesting story behind "You", the main character of the game. Unfortunately the game suffers of a certain repeatability which may cause some yawns in the second half of the adventure, and a confusing and rushed ending

Posted: May 2, 2012
												If you like the Silent Hill series, you will like Lone Survivor. It's a creepy, atmospheric survival horror game with an emphasis on keeping your character fed and well rested while exploring the dark world. The throwback SNES-style graphics work very well, and are obviously inspired by SNES classics like Splatterhouse and Clock Tower. The game does a good job of creating a constant sense of dread and unease, using music and screen effects, even breaking the fourth wall occasionally. If you've got $10 available, don't buy coffee and a vegemite scroll, buy this game instead because it's worth playing.

Posted: December 21, 2012
												I enjoyed this game, falling through all of its forlorn insanity. The narrative and the presentation will pull you through, with many questions and few answers. I guess some of the creepy bits could get to you due to amazing sound design, but how the protagonist ineracts with his reality, it never really struck me as horror. Absolutely worth a purchase and a play, even if you're not sure what you just played the past few hours, if for no other reason than to support more games like this trying new ways of storytelling with this much polish.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Lone Survivor is an odd puppy. It's a pixelated sidescrolling survival-horror that takes inspiration from many great places - most notably Silent Hill. You begin the game trapped on the second floor of an apartment building and must set to work finding a way out (for a start), while making sure to collect supplies, avoid (or kill) a good many monsters, look for other survivors, ocassionally obsess over cats, eat regularly, get a good night's sleep here and there, and most of all: stay sane. Which is easier said than done. It doesn't seem like you can ever truly screw up the game for good. Running out of bullets or dying is usually treated with a fever dream and some mercy supplies, but it puts a massive strain on your sanity. There are several endings, but the basic gist is that high sanity equals the good ending, low sanity equals a bad ending. Of course, what all effects your sanity - and how - is a much more complicated story indeed, and one you shall have to discover on your own.

And the Soundtrack let you immerse into this small, sick world completly.....but can you get out again?    :P

Posted: March 29, 2014
												The best Silent Hill-like since Konami's golden years on PlayStation (yes, even 'The Room' has its place and was genuinely good, shut up). Hardly reinvents the wheel, because it's a carbon copy of Team Silent's efforts down to the confirm prompt sound. As far as 2D-demake/homages go, it's the only one of its kind and offers some new things to the formula. With an emphasis on the actual survival part of horror, you'll be foraging for foodstuffs and making recipes to keep your health and sanity up. Then there's the way your actions (aggression vs stealth, consuming different meds, etc) affect the possible endings. As you would expect, these systems are a bit obscure, but the game drops hints throughout if you pay close attention. There are no puzzles to speak of, but there can be some frustrating trial and error sections to the game. Jasper Byrne is no Yamaoka, but the game feels built around the soundtrack - it's quite good.A note about the control scheme: it can't be rebound, so, oops.Everything else is solid if unremarkable; this is real survival horror in bite-sized pill form.

Posted: June 6, 2012
												A fantastic survival horror game with a distinct emphasis on survival.  Draws strong influence from Silent Hill series (no secret that the game's creator, Jasper Byrne, is a fan).  It feels like a 16-bit version of Silent Hill with a dash of Eternal Darkness thrown in.  You are a survivor of an outbreak that has devastated your city.  You awake in your apartment alone, supplies nearly exhausted and find yourself forced to confront the horrors outside to both gather life-sustaining supplies and perhaps find a way to escape the decaying city.  Along the way you will encounter mysterious figures and come to question which, if any, of these encounters even happened.  Unlike many run n' gun action survival horror games. Combat is not something encouraged and you must also take care of your basic biological needs such as eating and sleeping lest your mental health deteriorate and cause you to descend into madness.  It's a bit short but it's execution and artistic style are superb.

Posted: May 2, 2013
												A survival horror game which is ACTUALLY SCARY!? We haven't had one of those in a while. The game is one of the few survival horror games where surviving is actually difficult, as food and ammo is scarce, and your character is pretty useless at aiming at anything more than 2 meters away. Even your flashlight runs on batteries which you need to scavange for. You will spend a lot of the time making sure that your character is well rested and fed properly, as well as scavenging for ammo and later in the game flairs. The sheer tension created by the game is becoming rare in horror games in general nowadays, and it's nice to see a ruturn to psychological horror, instead of just jump scares and easily killable enemies. The main way this game does this isn't actually the surrealism of the story or the environment, or even the demonic, faceless monsters that you'll be facing, but the sound. Static starts playing whenever you're seen by an enemy, prompting you to run away or shoot it, and the little ambient sounds of the environment serve to make sure that you are fearing your next step. There are a lot of clever little things done with the music and sound which make the game a far better experience. The open eneded story is very enjoyable to play through, and many little things that you do in the game change the way it plays out. The only part I felt was out of place was a chase sequence in the middle which was mostly just memorizing paths, and the end boss, which was fairly dull and unimaginative, but other than that the enemies were terrifying and the story interesting and surreal. It's quite short, but you probably won't be able to do everything in your first playthrough, and maybe not even your second, so you won't be compeltly done with it for a while. All in all, it's an amazing game, and I would definitely reccomend it to anyone who likes survival horror games, or just games in general. I'm pretty sure it's also the first survival horror game in which you can adopt a cat. Get it.

Posted: September 12, 2012
												Lone Survivor is a brave experiment: attempting to bring a visceral horror experience with a distinctive 2D pixelated graphic is not a common thing, especially because the game must provide the player with a lot of atmosphere to make the imagination replacing what such simple graphic cannot show. To achieve this goal, J. Byrne decided to add some rpg elements to a classic side scrolling adventure game, like the necessity to properly rest and eat/drink while exploring the spectral and dangerous city. Ammunitions and supplies are scarse, enemies are tough and numerous, but exploring rewards the player with useful items. Several characters can be met during the travel, they have sidequests for the player and they also help to put together the pieces of the puzzle of a very interesting story behind "You", the main character of the game. Unfortunately the game suffers of a certain repeatability which may cause some yawns in the second half of the adventure, and a confusing and rushed ending

Posted: August 8, 2012
												An endearingly crafted story about the situation everyone dreams of but no one is ready for.  It's you, and you alone, against the hoard of monsters that have either killed everyone or left their spirits crushed and broken.  This is the apocalypse, and few games capture the desperation and everyday struggles of living as a dying race so thought-provokingly.The gameplay is all about planning, exploration, and resourcefulness.  The story itself is provocative and timeless, as we go into the mind of a man forced to reconcile the past so he can survive the present.  Twists and turns abound in this indie title, so get ready for a brainbender.  The graphics evoke a simpler time, and it's a shame this game was never officially on the SNES.  If you are looking for a psychological journey with a dark premise, desperate situations, and retro graphics, then this is the place.  Lone survivor delivers exactly what it promises and then some.

Posted: May 2, 2013
												A survival horror game which is ACTUALLY SCARY!? We haven't had one of those in a while. The game is one of the few survival horror games where surviving is actually difficult, as food and ammo is scarce, and your character is pretty useless at aiming at anything more than 2 meters away. Even your flashlight runs on batteries which you need to scavange for. You will spend a lot of the time making sure that your character is well rested and fed properly, as well as scavenging for ammo and later in the game flairs. The sheer tension created by the game is becoming rare in horror games in general nowadays, and it's nice to see a ruturn to psychological horror, instead of just jump scares and easily killable enemies. The main way this game does this isn't actually the surrealism of the story or the environment, or even the demonic, faceless monsters that you'll be facing, but the sound. Static starts playing whenever you're seen by an enemy, prompting you to run away or shoot it, and the little ambient sounds of the environment serve to make sure that you are fearing your next step. There are a lot of clever little things done with the music and sound which make the game a far better experience. The open eneded story is very enjoyable to play through, and many little things that you do in the game change the way it plays out. The only part I felt was out of place was a chase sequence in the middle which was mostly just memorizing paths, and the end boss, which was fairly dull and unimaginative, but other than that the enemies were terrifying and the story interesting and surreal. It's quite short, but you probably won't be able to do everything in your first playthrough, and maybe not even your second, so you won't be compeltly done with it for a while. All in all, it's an amazing game, and I would definitely reccomend it to anyone who likes survival horror games, or just games in general. I'm pretty sure it's also the first survival horror game in which you can adopt a cat. Get it.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Lone Survivor is an odd puppy. It's a pixelated sidescrolling survival-horror that takes inspiration from many great places - most notably Silent Hill. You begin the game trapped on the second floor of an apartment building and must set to work finding a way out (for a start), while making sure to collect supplies, avoid (or kill) a good many monsters, look for other survivors, ocassionally obsess over cats, eat regularly, get a good night's sleep here and there, and most of all: stay sane. Which is easier said than done. It doesn't seem like you can ever truly screw up the game for good. Running out of bullets or dying is usually treated with a fever dream and some mercy supplies, but it puts a massive strain on your sanity. There are several endings, but the basic gist is that high sanity equals the good ending, low sanity equals a bad ending. Of course, what all effects your sanity - and how - is a much more complicated story indeed, and one you shall have to discover on your own.

Posted: June 16, 2012
												One of my favorite things about this game isn't the atmosphere or the choices you can make (which is done very effectively and requires some thought). But the characters themselves. A cross between all in the main character's head and generally nice or partially helpful characters litter the game which liven up the dank depressing mood.In fact, since I played the game on a pacifist run I found that underneath the depressing "dog-eat-dog" atmosphere, there's some genuine hope and optimism. It gives you such a warm fuzzy feeling to pick up a can of beans and know that it will be a delicious treat tomorrow along with your morning coffee. The main character's reaction is not only the icing, but the cake itself. Treating mental disorders has never felt so nice.That said, the difficulty flucuates from easy to hard and back to easy around the midpoint and the game requires a lot of guessing to figure out (drinking milk to get the milk bottles for bottles of water).

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Despite being fairly short, this is one game that horror fans shouldn't miss.  As the lone survivor (teehee) of some unknown apocalyptic disaster or outbreak, you must struggle to survive on your own with your life and sanity intact.  The game focuses very much on psychological horror.  It opts for a very tense and oppressive atmosphere rather than jump scares and over the top horror cliches.  It can be argued that horror is one of the most difficult genres to break into.  Fear is a subjective response and what frightens one person may not frighten another.  While there wasn't anything that made me reach for a new pair of pants, I was certainly on the edge of my seat the entire time.  In my opinion, the best horror games are those that make you incredibly tense and afraid of the unkown.  They make your body cry out for you to quit, they make you hesitant to press on, while at the same time making you crave more.  This game did it for me, and I hope it will for you as well.In conclusion, Lone Survivor is a great horror game.  It's certainly not without it's flaws (which I haven't covered here, because they truly are minor), but will certainly not disappoint.

												This one is not as good as everyone says.The protagonist is boring and lifeless, and I guessed the twist ending ten minutes in. The writing is competent but uninspiring. There really is nothing in the story department that you haven't seen before.Gameplay is repetitious. You'll spend a lot of time backtracking through the same samey areas over and over. Your character is in constant need of rest or food, which is more annoying than compelling. The food crafting system is bizarrely over-complex, and entails a lot of time spent struggling with the terrible interface. Speaking of...Controls are baffling laid-out. Presumably this is meant to make combat more stressful and convey that our character is not some bad♥♥♥♥♥super soldier, but in reality it just means looking away from the game at your keyboard to realign your fingers every time you need to do anything other than walk and look at stuff. The hotkeys are a total joke.If you get it as part of a bundle, it might be worth your time to try it out, but I cannot recommend buying this game.

Posted: May 8, 2015
												Today at Great Games with Wolf (Issue #1) : Lone Survivor."My name is....Doesn't really matter, I suppose.Used to know how long I've been hereNow I've got no idea."great psicological adventure that dares the player to fight their most intricate fears and question its reality, As you embody the nameless survivor you must face the harsh world that's left behind after a catastrophic-Apocaliptic-esque infection.While this game uses very common horror concepts like a dystopic world ravaged by an unknown infection and zombie-like enemies it still manages to avoid the "More of the same media" Gap by throwing a really fragile (Both Physically and Psicologically) protagonist to the mix, the same character clearly suffers from a severe case of depression (given all the horrors he has faced alone) and manages to transmit that feeling to the player, The post-apocalyptic world is indeed a nightmare, Not a bullet-frenzy zombie killing spree that some other media has led us to believe so many times before.With intricate dialogue that usually includes personification of inanimate objects and self-loathing and some hallucinations the player gets to know the background story, It would seem unexistan given that it's not directly narrated but on the contrary, it's there, waiting for you to figure it out by yourself.As you progress through the story you will notice that the survivor will often hallucinate talking with a variety of characters, often passes-out and even finds himself unable to remember doing some things (like writing on his diary). as you struggle to find food, water and enough sleep while you evade the nightmarish creatures the horrors take it's toll on the survivor's mind making the setting all the more depresing.speaking about combat and scavenging, both dynamics are present and are a core feature of the game, you have to eat to stay alive, and not just "Eat anything". Eating rotten meat and rats will allow you to stay alive, but also have a higher negative impact on the character's sanity than taking the time to find and cook the ingredients for a propper meal (even when that meal canned beans). sleep is also necesary to keep you sane, and getting too much or not enough will affect your final sanity. The combat is Reminiscent of the golden days of resident evil, only in 2D. and while it lacks the weapon variety of the former it compensates by giving you the chance to clear the whole game without firing a single bullet, Using your wits and stealth to traverse the infected-filled streets.While the creatures in the world are few in variation the character stays human and vulnerable the whole game, Making the first enemy as deadly as the last one. nonetheless the game also pushes some interesting variations to keep your♥♥♥♥♥♥scared and some giant scary monsters to keep things interesting.My final rating: 9/10Brilliantly executed.

Posted: September 12, 2012
												Lone Survivor is a brave experiment: attempting to bring a visceral horror experience with a distinctive 2D pixelated graphic is not a common thing, especially because the game must provide the player with a lot of atmosphere to make the imagination replacing what such simple graphic cannot show. To achieve this goal, J. Byrne decided to add some rpg elements to a classic side scrolling adventure game, like the necessity to properly rest and eat/drink while exploring the spectral and dangerous city. Ammunitions and supplies are scarse, enemies are tough and numerous, but exploring rewards the player with useful items. Several characters can be met during the travel, they have sidequests for the player and they also help to put together the pieces of the puzzle of a very interesting story behind "You", the main character of the game. Unfortunately the game suffers of a certain repeatability which may cause some yawns in the second half of the adventure, and a confusing and rushed ending
